citation.article-title: Rhodobacter aestuarii sp. nov., a phototrophic alphaproteobacterium isolated from an estuarine environment.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Rhodobacter aestuarii sp. nov.
Rhodobacter aestuarii (aes.tu.a′ri.i. L. gen. n. aestuarii of the estuary, the environment from which the type strain was isolated).
Cells are ovoid to rod-shaped, 0.7–1.0 μm wide and 1.5–2.0 μm long, are motile, divide by binary fission and form chains of four to eight cells.
Growth occurs under anaerobic conditions in the light (photo-organoheterotrophy) or under aerobic conditions in the dark (chemo-organoheterotrophy).
Internal photosynthetic membranes are of the vesicular type.
The colour of phototrophic cultures is yellowish green.
Bacteriochlorophyll a and the carotenoids spheroidene and spheroidenone are present.
Substrates that are utilized as carbon sources and electron donors under photo-organoheterotrophic conditions include pyruvate and lactate.
NaCl is not required for growth, but is tolerated up to 2 % (w/v).
Grows at pH 6.0–8.5 (optimum at pH 7.0) and 25–35 °C (optimum at 30 °C).
Thiamine is required as growth factor.
C18 : 1ω7c is the dominant fatty acid; small amounts of C18 : 0 2-OH, C18 : 0, C16 : 0 and C10 : 0 3-OH are also found.
Photolithoautotrophy, chemolithoautotrophy and fermentative growth have not been demonstrated.
The type strain is JA296T (=JCM 14887T =CCUG 55130T), isolated from a brown-coloured microbial mat from brackish water of Bhitarkanika mangrove forest, Dangmal, Orissa, India.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 65.1 mol% (by HPLC).
